awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Impact of Convectively-Generated Gravity Waves on Mesoscale Convective Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Gravity waves, generated by thunderstorms, are commonly associated with nighttime thunderstorm clusters called "Mesoscale Convective Systems" (MCSs); storm systems that are frequent producers of heavy rainfall and damaging winds.  These gravity waves modify both the environment surrounding the MCS and its internal circulation.  Considering that even small changes in the surrounding environment or internal circulation have been shown to affect MCS development, improved understanding of these wave processes is important to successful MCS prediction.  Gravity waves have been linked to storm intensification and potential severe weather, so improved understanding of these features would lead to improved immediate, short-term forecasts of severe weather risks.  This research supports an early career female investigator and one graduate student, and also involves a collaboration between a university and private industry involved in atmospheric research.  

Knowledge of the MCS gravity wave generation-feedback process, including the influence of microphysical perturbations on this process, will lead to better understanding of MCS development, as well as the sensitivity of convection to these environmental changes. Understanding the extent to which changes in the environment due to convectively generated gravity waves need to be captured to correctly simulate MCSs is a significant step to understanding MCS predictability.  Furthermore, knowledge of the gravity wave characteristics produced by an MCS allows inferences to be made about the phase, depth, and intensity of the latent heating profile without direct microphysical observations that can be resource-intensive to obtain. Understanding of the influence of microphysical perturbations upon the generation and impacts of gravity waves will be useful in microphysical parameterization development, leading to better numerical model prediction of convection in general.  Model simulations will be compared against actual data from the Plains Elevated Convection at Night (PECAN) Field Campaign.

por.por_cntn:
Organized groupings of thunderstorms, referred to as Mesoscale Convective Systems (MCSs), are frequent producers of heavy rainfall and damaging winds. MCSs also produce gravity waves---"ripples" in the air surrounding the storms--- which can modify the nearby temperature, humidity, and wind. Considering that even small changes in the surrounding environment or internal circulation have been shown to affect MCS development, improved understanding of these wave processes is important to successful MCS prediction.

This project used observations of MCSs, along with numerical models of the atmosphere, to carefully analyze the influences of convectively generated gravity waves on the surrounding environment, and in turn influence the behavior of the MCS itself. Previous research on these gravity waves has focused on a fairly limited set of scenarios, and this research extended that knowledge by examining a broader range of environments. In particular, the temperature, humidity, and wind conditions surrounding the simulated MCS were varied from idealized scenarios, to those representing observed nocturnal MCSs in the central United States. For example, within a nocturnal environment, the frequency of the cellularity of updrafts increases, subsequently increasing the frequency of wave generation. When deep vertical wind shear was incorporated, many of the low-frequency waves were strong enough to support cloud development ahead of the MCS as well as sustain and support convection. This new knowledge primarily made up the MS thesis research for a graduate student, and was published in peer-reviewed articles.

This project also enabled research into a high-impact windstorm in Colorado in June 2020, and how it was connected to gravity wave processes. This line of storms produced the strongest measured thunderstorm wind gust on record for Colorado, at 50.45 m/s or 113 mph. Unique, high-resolution observations of this storm were obtained and used to quantify the rapid fluctuations in temperature, pressure, and very strong winds in this event. Numerical models have also been used to understand the key processes in this unusual event.

This project fostered a collaboration between a university and private research organization, and the co-mentorship of graduate students by scientists from these different career paths to provide varied perspectives on future careers.


Last Modified: 03/02/2022
Modified by: Russ S Schumacher
